conversations.content: The Finality of Death: Part One
The flame of life that once burned bright within the sacred bird sputtered to a halt. And from the ashes, three Phoenix sisters arose.
Phoenix, maiden of reincarnation. Dark Phoenix, arbiter of lifespans. And Corsaint Phoenix, regenerant.
＂Whether wound or illness, you need only speak what ails, and I will heal! Regeneration is my life; my calling!＂ Corsaint Phoenix quite liked her power, for it brought happiness to all.
But one day, Corsaint Phoenix was suddenly wracked with doubt.
＂Is there meaning in regeneration? After all, no matter how many times someone is healed, death comes for us all in the end.＂
As the days passed, her heart wavered, and slowly did the seed of doubt begin to take root. Listless and negligent, she allowed a single life to slip through her fingers.
＂Huh? I...failed?＂ Corsaint Phoenix was dumbfounded. ＂Worry not. I will help you.＂ Phoenix had come along, and, unable to sit idly by, held a hand over the corpse.
In the blink of an eye, she restored life to the empty vessel. ＂A soul that could not be healed in life passes on, opening the door to reincarnation.＂ Phoenix's tone was stern but gentle.
The notion further shrouded Corsaint Phoenix's heart in doubt. ＂What place does regeneration have when there exists a power so mighty as reincarnation?＂
If her role was unnecessary, why should she persist in it? She chose to quit her work and live her own life. Without healing, disease spread, and death and sadness reigned.
She felt a rueful tickle at her heart, but resolved to turn a blind eye to the world's suffering all the same.
She walked on, traversing a stagnant river, a wild plain, and a wasted wood. And at the end of the wasteland, she came upon a lone foal, fallen and exhausted.
She alone could help this animal, abandoned and in need. Reluctantly, Corsaint Phoenix used her power of regeneration on the foal. Its vitality restored, it posed her a question.
＂Thank you, miss. I am all alone. Are...you alone, too?＂ Corsaint Phoenix nodded. Each had drunk deeply of solitude's bitter draught. They grew close in no time at all.
They were inseparable. When the foal fell ill, she healed it immediately. And before she realized it, the foal had grown into an old horse. Their days passed without incident.
Yet even the happiest times must eventually come to an end. And on one winter day like so many before, Corsaint Phoenix was faced with an immutable principle.
The Finality of Death: Part Two
Unable to find meaning in her power of regeneration, Corsaint Phoenix cast aside her role and lived freely.
Treading the path of freedom, she befriended a lone horse, and the two shared many joyful years together. However...
One harsh winter, the old horse was stricken with illness. As always, Corsaint Phoenix tried to heal it, but try as she might, the horse's suffering would not recede.
With fear festering in the pit of her stomach, she tried once more to use her power of regeneration. And yet the illness would not abate, and instead only grew worse.
＂Why? Why won't you get better? I have nothing to my name save this power of regeneration, and now even that is wrested from my grasp?＂
The horse stood on the precipice of death, its illness fatal. Corsaint Phoenix broke down in tears. As she did, the horse looked upon her and smiled gently, speaking thus:
＂This malady will soon take me, but grieve not. I have lived a long enough life, and my happiness has been immeasurable.＂
＂While I cannot stay with you any longer, my memory will live on within you forever. May it be the key to unshackle your burdened heart.＂
These were the horse's last words. Only its lifeless body remained. Corsaint Phoenix wept as she rushed back to Phoenix's side.
＂Please, reincarnate this horse! I wish to speak with it once more, no matter the cost! Please, I'll do anything!＂
In light of this extraordinary situation, Phoenix set to her task. The horse's soul returned in the form of a foal, and Corsaint Phoenix wept once again—this time with joy.
＂Who are you, miss?＂
Corsaint Phoenix was frozen in place. The life before her was wholly new. No trace of the horse's old memories remained in the reincarnated foal.
＂I finally understand. The power of reincarnation is no substitute for the power of regeneration. Yet my friend's memory lives on...in my heart alone.＂
All life meets its end eventually. Yet regeneration is far from futile. Armed with a new sense of purpose, Corsaint Phoenix resumed her duty.
To this day, the white dragon carries a precious memory of a dear friend: A memory of a horse, galloping over a distant plain, transcending time through the threshold to her heart.
